title: My Lab Journal
text: This is a template example for lab journaling. Students in the data science courses at the Institute of Entrepreneurship will use this template to learn R for business analytics. Students can replace this text as they wish.

title: My Lab Journal
text:
How to use

Accept the assignment and get your own github repo.
Blog/journal what you are doing in R, by editing the .qmd files.
See the links page for lots of helpful links on learning R.
Change everything to make it your own.
Make sure to render you website every time before you want to upload changes.

title: Statistical Concepts
text:
1 Assignmnet

# Load the file
random_vars <- readRDS("Causal_Data_Science_Data/random_vars.rds")
str(random_vars)

#> Classes 'tbl_df', 'tbl' and 'data.frame':    1000 obs. of  2 variables:
#>  $ age   : num  21 34 10 68 15 50 32 14 17 26 ...
#>  $ income: num  940 6678 22 2392 74 ...

# Create a Data Frame
df1=data.frame(random_vars)
# 1.Find the values of mean, variance and standard deviation


# 1.Mean 
mean(df1$age)

#> [1] 33.471

mean(df1$income)

#> [1] 3510.731



# 2. Variance
var(df1$age)

#> [1] 340.6078

var(df1$income)

#> [1] 8625646



# 3. Standard deviation
sd(df1$age)

#> [1] 18.45556

sd(df1$income)

#> [1] 2936.945



# 2. The calculated Standard deviations are on vastly different scales. In this case, the large difference in values suggests that the Data Sets corresponding to these standard deviations have very different degrees of variability. Due to this reason it does not make sense to compare them.


# 3 Calculate Covariance and Correlation
cov(df1)

#>               age     income
#> age      340.6078   29700.15
#> income 29700.1468 8625645.84



cor(df1)

#>              age    income
#> age    1.0000000 0.5479432
#> income 0.5479432 1.0000000



# 4. Correlation is generally easier to interpret and compare than covariance especially when dealing with variables on different scales.It provides a standardized measure of the strength and direction of the linear relationship between two variables.


# 5. Conditional Expected value
age_18 <- subset(df1, age<=18, select = c(age,income))
mean(age_18$income)

#> [1] 389.6074



age_65 <- subset(df1, age>=65, select = c(age,income))
mean(age_65$income)

#> [1] 1777.237



age_18_65 <- subset(df1, age>=18 & age<65, select = c(age,income))
mean(age_18_65$income)

#> [1] 4685.734

title: Causality
text:
1 Assignment

# Load necessary libraries
library(tidyverse)

#> ── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
#> ✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.4
#> ✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.0
#> ✔ ggplot2   3.4.4     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
#> ✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tidyr     1.3.0
#> ✔ purrr     1.0.2     
#> ── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
#> ✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
#> ✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
#> ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

library(ggplot2)


# Set seed for reproducibility
set.seed(123)


# Generate random data for two variables
n <- 50
x <- rnorm(n)
y <- 0.8*x + rnorm(n)


# Create a data frame
data <- data.frame(x = x, y = y)


# Create a scatter plot with a regression line
ggplot(data, aes(x, y)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE, color = "blue") +
  labs(title = "Spurious Correlation",
       x = "X Variable",
       y = "Y Variable") +
  theme_minimal()

#> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

title: Probability Theory
text:
Note



You can delete everything in here and start fresh.
This is a .qmd file. It is plain text with special features. Any time you write just like this, it will be compiled to normal text in the website. If you put a # in front of your text, it will create a top level-header.
To learn more about Quarto websites visit https://quarto.org/docs/websites.

title: Regression and Statistical Inference
text:
1 Assignmnet

library(tidyverse)

#> ── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
#> ✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.4
#> ✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.0
#> ✔ ggplot2   3.4.4     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
#> ✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tidyr     1.3.0
#> ✔ purrr     1.0.2     
#> ── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
#> ✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
#> ✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
#> ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors



# Load the file
car_prices <- readRDS("Causal_Data_Science_Data/car_prices.rds")
# Create a Data Frame
df=data.frame(car_prices)


# 1 Check the dimensions
dim(df)

#> [1] 181  22



# 181 rows and 22 columns


head(df)



  


df



  




glimpse(df)

#> Rows: 181
#> Columns: 22
#> $ aspiration       <chr> "std", "std", "std", "std", "std", "std", "std", "std…
#> $ doornumber       <chr> "two", "two", "two", "four", "four", "two", "four", "…
#> $ carbody          <chr> "convertible", "convertible", "hatchback", "sedan", "…
#> $ drivewheel       <chr> "rwd", "rwd", "rwd", "fwd", "4wd", "fwd", "fwd", "fwd…
#> $ enginelocation   <chr> "front", "front", "front", "front", "front", "front",…
#> $ wheelbase        <dbl> 88.6, 88.6, 94.5, 99.8, 99.4, 99.8, 105.8, 105.8, 105…
#> $ carlength        <dbl> 168.8, 168.8, 171.2, 176.6, 176.6, 177.3, 192.7, 192.…
#> $ carwidth         <dbl> 64.1, 64.1, 65.5, 66.2, 66.4, 66.3, 71.4, 71.4, 71.4,…
#> $ carheight        <dbl> 48.8, 48.8, 52.4, 54.3, 54.3, 53.1, 55.7, 55.7, 55.9,…
#> $ curbweight       <dbl> 2548, 2548, 2823, 2337, 2824, 2507, 2844, 2954, 3086,…
#> $ enginetype       <chr> "dohc", "dohc", "ohcv", "ohc", "ohc", "ohc", "ohc", "…
#> $ cylindernumber   <chr> "four", "four", "six", "four", "five", "five", "five"…
#> $ enginesize       <dbl> 130, 130, 152, 109, 136, 136, 136, 136, 131, 131, 108…
#> $ fuelsystem       <chr> "mpfi", "mpfi", "mpfi", "mpfi", "mpfi", "mpfi", "mpfi…
#> $ boreratio        <dbl> 3.47, 3.47, 2.68, 3.19, 3.19, 3.19, 3.19, 3.19, 3.13,…
#> $ stroke           <dbl> 2.68, 2.68, 3.47, 3.40, 3.40, 3.40, 3.40, 3.40, 3.40,…
#> $ compressionratio <dbl> 9.00, 9.00, 9.00, 10.00, 8.00, 8.50, 8.50, 8.50, 8.30…
#> $ horsepower       <dbl> 111, 111, 154, 102, 115, 110, 110, 110, 140, 160, 101…
#> $ peakrpm          <dbl> 5000, 5000, 5000, 5500, 5500, 5500, 5500, 5500, 5500,…
#> $ citympg          <dbl> 21, 21, 19, 24, 18, 19, 19, 19, 17, 16, 23, 23, 21, 2…
#> $ highwaympg       <dbl> 27, 27, 26, 30, 22, 25, 25, 25, 20, 22, 29, 29, 28, 2…
#> $ price            <dbl> 13495.00, 16500.00, 16500.00, 13950.00, 17450.00, 152…



summary(df)

#>   aspiration         doornumber          carbody           drivewheel       
#>  Length:181         Length:181         Length:181         Length:181        
#>  Class :character   Class :character   Class :character   Class :character  
#>  Mode  :character   Mode  :character   Mode  :character   Mode  :character  
#>                                                                             
#>                                                                             
#>                                                                             
#>  enginelocation       wheelbase        carlength        carwidth    
#>  Length:181         Min.   : 86.60   Min.   :141.1   Min.   :60.30  
#>  Class :character   1st Qu.: 94.50   1st Qu.:166.3   1st Qu.:64.00  
#>  Mode  :character   Median : 96.50   Median :173.0   Median :65.40  
#>                     Mean   : 98.21   Mean   :173.3   Mean   :65.74  
#>                     3rd Qu.:100.40   3rd Qu.:180.2   3rd Qu.:66.50  
#>                     Max.   :120.90   Max.   :208.1   Max.   :72.30  
#>    carheight       curbweight    enginetype        cylindernumber    
#>  Min.   :47.80   Min.   :1488   Length:181         Length:181        
#>  1st Qu.:52.00   1st Qu.:2122   Class :character   Class :character  
#>  Median :53.70   Median :2410   Mode  :character   Mode  :character  
#>  Mean   :53.58   Mean   :2521                                        
#>  3rd Qu.:55.50   3rd Qu.:2910                                        
#>  Max.   :59.80   Max.   :4066                                        
#>    enginesize     fuelsystem          boreratio         stroke    
#>  Min.   : 61.0   Length:181         Min.   :2.540   Min.   :2.07  
#>  1st Qu.: 98.0   Class :character   1st Qu.:3.150   1st Qu.:3.08  
#>  Median :120.0   Mode  :character   Median :3.310   Median :3.23  
#>  Mean   :127.1                      Mean   :3.325   Mean   :3.23  
#>  3rd Qu.:141.0                      3rd Qu.:3.590   3rd Qu.:3.40  
#>  Max.   :326.0                      Max.   :3.940   Max.   :4.17  
#>  compressionratio   horsepower       peakrpm        citympg     
#>  Min.   : 7.000   Min.   : 48.0   Min.   :4200   Min.   :13.00  
#>  1st Qu.: 8.500   1st Qu.: 70.0   1st Qu.:4800   1st Qu.:19.00  
#>  Median : 9.000   Median : 95.0   Median :5200   Median :24.00  
#>  Mean   : 8.848   Mean   :106.2   Mean   :5182   Mean   :24.85  
#>  3rd Qu.: 9.400   3rd Qu.:116.0   3rd Qu.:5500   3rd Qu.:30.00  
#>  Max.   :11.500   Max.   :288.0   Max.   :6600   Max.   :49.00  
#>    highwaympg        price      
#>  Min.   :16.00   Min.   : 5118  
#>  1st Qu.:25.00   1st Qu.: 7609  
#>  Median :30.00   Median : 9980  
#>  Mean   :30.48   Mean   :12999  
#>  3rd Qu.:34.00   3rd Qu.:16430  
#>  Max.   :54.00   Max.   :45400



# 2. The data types present are character and double data type.


# 3. Linear regression
lm_all <- lm(price ~ ., data = df)
summary(lm_all)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = price ~ ., data = df)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>    Min     1Q Median     3Q    Max 
#>  -5662  -1120      0    798   9040 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                        Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)          -36269.965  15460.866  -2.346 0.020354 *  
#> aspirationturbo        1846.206   1041.391   1.773 0.078386 .  
#> doornumbertwo           242.523    571.929   0.424 0.672172    
#> carbodyhardtop        -3691.743   1424.825  -2.591 0.010561 *  
#> carbodyhatchback      -3344.335   1238.359  -2.701 0.007757 ** 
#> carbodysedan          -2292.820   1356.014  -1.691 0.093043 .  
#> carbodywagon          -3427.921   1490.285  -2.300 0.022885 *  
#> drivewheelfwd          -504.564   1076.623  -0.469 0.640030    
#> drivewheelrwd           -15.446   1268.070  -0.012 0.990299    
#> enginelocationrear     6643.492   2572.275   2.583 0.010806 *  
#> wheelbase               -30.197     92.776  -0.325 0.745294    
#> carlength               -29.740     51.672  -0.576 0.565824    
#> carwidth                731.819    244.533   2.993 0.003258 ** 
#> carheight               123.195    134.607   0.915 0.361617    
#> curbweight                2.612      1.781   1.467 0.144706    
#> enginetypedohcv       -8541.957   4749.685  -1.798 0.074219 .  
#> enginetypel             978.748   1786.384   0.548 0.584619    
#> enginetypeohc          3345.252    933.001   3.585 0.000461 ***
#> enginetypeohcf          972.919   1625.631   0.598 0.550462    
#> enginetypeohcv        -6222.322   1236.415  -5.033 1.43e-06 ***
#> cylindernumberfive   -11724.540   3019.192  -3.883 0.000157 ***
#> cylindernumberfour   -11549.326   3177.177  -3.635 0.000387 ***
#> cylindernumbersix     -7151.398   2247.230  -3.182 0.001793 ** 
#> cylindernumberthree   -4318.929   4688.833  -0.921 0.358545    
#> cylindernumbertwelve -11122.209   4196.494  -2.650 0.008946 ** 
#> enginesize              125.934     26.541   4.745 5.00e-06 ***
#> fuelsystem2bbl          177.136    883.615   0.200 0.841400    
#> fuelsystemmfi         -3041.018   2576.996  -1.180 0.239934    
#> fuelsystemmpfi          359.278   1001.529   0.359 0.720326    
#> fuelsystemspdi        -2543.890   1363.546  -1.866 0.064140 .  
#> fuelsystemspfi          514.766   2499.229   0.206 0.837107    
#> boreratio             -1306.740   1642.221  -0.796 0.427516    
#> stroke                -4527.137    922.732  -4.906 2.49e-06 ***
#> compressionratio       -737.901    555.960  -1.327 0.186539    
#> horsepower               10.293     22.709   0.453 0.651035    
#> peakrpm                   2.526      0.634   3.983 0.000108 ***
#> citympg                 -90.352    166.647  -0.542 0.588538    
#> highwaympg              154.858    167.148   0.926 0.355761    
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 2189 on 143 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.9415, Adjusted R-squared:  0.9264 
#> F-statistic: 62.21 on 37 and 143 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16



# 4 Choosing a regressor
lm_imp <- lm(price ~ enginesize , data = df)
summary(lm_imp)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = price ~ enginesize, data = df)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>      Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
#> -10818.6  -1969.6   -168.6   1494.0  14393.9 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>              Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept) -8622.296    873.535  -9.871   <2e-16 ***
#> enginesize    170.064      6.523  26.073   <2e-16 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 3694 on 179 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.7916, Adjusted R-squared:  0.7904 
#> F-statistic: 679.8 on 1 and 179 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16



# 4.1 The regressor used was enginesize and it belongs to the numeric variables (discrete/continous). It can take numeric values
# 4.2 As our estimate is positive (170.064), we have a positive effect. As a result increasing the enginesize would increase the price of the car.
# 4.3 Yes, it  is satistically significant as the p value is lower than our significance level (0.05)


# 5 Adding a new variable
df %>% mutate(seatheating = TRUE)



  




# Changing the variables from logical variables to numerical variables
df1<- df %>% mutate(seatheating = 1)
df1



  




# New regression
lm_new <- lm(price ~ seatheating , data = df1)
summary(lm_new)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = price ~ seatheating, data = df1)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>    Min     1Q Median     3Q    Max 
#>  -7881  -5390  -3019   3431  32401 
#> 
#> Coefficients: (1 not defined because of singularities)
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)  12999.4      599.7   21.68   <2e-16 ***
#> seatheating       NA         NA      NA       NA    
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 8068 on 180 degrees of freedom



# There is no coefficient for this regression as there is no relation between seat heating and pricing.
